bioghist.p: Robert Elliott Speer (1867-1947) was one of the leaders of the Protestant missionary movement in the first half of the 20th century. In this capacity, he made many trips to the Far East and to South America. His wife was Emma (Doll) Bailey Speer (1872-1961). She attended Bryn Mawr College from 1890 to 1892. She worked throughout her lifetime for the Young Women's Christian Association, assuming the presidency of the National Board in 1915. Their daughter, Margaret Bailey Speer also attended Bryn Mawr College, graduating in 1922. She was a teacher, and traveled to China in 1925 as part of a Presbytarian mission to teach English at the Women's College at Yenching. Upon the outbreak of war in 1941, she was detained by the Japanese, not returning to the United States until 1943. After her return she assumed the post of headmistress of the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr. William McMurtrie Speer (1865-1923) was Robert Elliott Speer's brother. He was a newspaperman and lawyer.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the papers of the Speer family. Materials are divided into four major series for Robert Elliott Speer, Emma Bailey Speer, Margaret Bailey Speer, and Robert Milton Speer. The Robert Elliott Speer papers include letters to his wife and children, diairies, scrapbooks, account books, and photos. This portion of the collection also includes correspondence of his father, Robert Milton Speer (1838-1890), U.S. representative from Pennsylvania, to family members. The Emma Bailey Speer papers include letters to her husband, family and friends; diaries, talks, speeches, and notebooks, primarily concerning family matters. Correspondents include Herbert Hoover, Elizabeth Morrow, and John D. Rockefeller. The Margaret Bailey Speer papers chiefly consists of letters (1925-1942) to her parents relating to her activities as dean of the women's college at Yenching University, Peking, China. This section of the collection also includes letters to other family members, and speeches and talks (1943-1965) to students and other groups, given while Speer was headmistress at the Shipley School. The Robert Milton Speer papers includes correspondence with family members, including his parents, U.S. representative Robert Milton (1838-1890) and Martha Ellen (McMurtrie) Speer; and brothers, Robert Elliott (1867-1947) and Victor (1872-1905) Speer. These papers include records of Robert Milton Speer's political career representing Pennsylvania (1871-1875), and Victor's correspondence with family members. In addition to these four major sections, the collection also includes genealogical materials on the Elder family, religious pamphlets written by Emma Bailey Speer, and printed articles by Margaret Bailey Speer on her work in China.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
